metadata.case_name: Company (manufacturing barrels and drums) v. Workmen

facts.text: Appellant is a company manufacturing barrels and drums at Bombay.
Dispute between appellant and its workmen referred to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay by Government of Bombay on November 17, 1955 (Reference I.T. No. 166 of 1955).
Workmen claimed (i) four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus for the year 1952, (ii) retrospective operation of wage-scale from March 1, 1952.

Appellant agreed to wage scale suggested by tribunal but opposed retrospective operation due to deliberate slowing down of production (go-slow) in previous years; wanted increased wages linked to guaranteed production.
Tribunal found some justification in appellant's contention of considerable go-slow affecting production.
Tribunal awarded retrospective effect to wage increase from June 1, 1956; recommended appointment of expert for guaranteed production.
Tribunal awarded five months basic wages as bonus for 1952.

Gross profit: Rs. 5.05 lacs; depreciation Rs. 1.36 lacs; balance Rs. 3.69 lacs; income-tax Rs. 1.61 lacs; interest on capital Rs. 16,000; available surplus Rs. 1.92 lacs; bonus Rs. 91,000; rebate Rs. 40,000; left with appellant Rs. 1.01 lacs (or Rs. 1.41 lacs per tribunal).
Actual income-tax assessment after tribunal order: Rs. 2.35 lacs.

legal_issues.text: Whether retrospective operation should be given to the order of the Industrial Tribunal relating to increase in wages.

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal having found justification in contention of considerable go-slow should not have given retrospective effect to wage increase.
Increased wages should be linked to guaranteed production.
Tribunal could not award more than claimed four months wages including DA as bonus.
Tribunal did not account for rehabilitation.
Actual income-tax of Rs. 2.35 lacs should be deducted, not notional Rs. 1.61 lacs.

respondent_arguments.text: Claimed four months wages including dearness allowance as bonus for 1952.
Retrospective operation of wage-scale from March 1, 1952.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal considered go-slow fully and fixed retrospective from June 1, 1956, rejecting claim from March 1952; not truly retrospective as reference in Nov 1955.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to interfere with tribunal's date of June 1, 1956.

court_reasoning.text: Five months basic wages less than claimed four months wages incl DA; tribunal had jurisdiction to award.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim was four months wages including DA, award lower.

court_reasoning.text: Bonus calculation per Full Bench formula upheld: available surplus supports five months bonus; even with rehabilitation Rs. 40,000, surplus remains.
For Full Bench formula, deduct notional income-tax per formula, not actual assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal concerned with formula, not actual IT paid.

holdings.text: No interference with tribunal's order giving retrospective effect to wage increase from June 1, 1956.
Tribunal justified in awarding five months basic wages as bonus per Full Bench formula.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; tribunal's award on retrospective wages from June 1, 1956 and five months bonus upheld; no interference with tribunal's findings and calculations.

key_quotes.text: This could hardly be called retrospective considering that the reference was made in November 1955.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: For the purpose of the Full Bench formula, the income-tax payable has to be deducted on the figures worked out according to the formula.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies use of notional vs actual income-tax in bonus formula.
